ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The words or language units by which a thing is known.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A subtype of antigen-experienced CD4+ T cells that are primarily found within B cell follicles near the periphery of secondary lymphoid organs and are involved in the formation and maintenance of germinal centers. These cells express CXCR5 and CD40L and secrete IL-21 and IL-4.

Concepts.definition: A subtype of antigen-experienced CD4+ T cells that are primarily found within B cell follicles near the periphery of secondary lymphoid organs and are involved in the formation and maintenance of germinal centers. These cells express CXCR5 and CD40L and secrete IL-21 and IL-4.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: This gene is involved in T-cell mediation and receptor signal transduction.: Typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.

Concepts.definition: This gene is involved in T-cell mediation and receptor signal transduction.
Typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: This gene is involved in immune function.: Typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.

Concepts.definition: This gene is involved in immune function.
Typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: This gene is involved in the regulation of apoptosis, inflammatory responses, and immune responses.: Typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.

Concepts.definition: This gene is involved in the regulation of apoptosis, inflammatory responses, and immune responses.
Typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: This gene is involved in maintenance of T cell immunity.: Typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.

Concepts.definition: This gene is involved in maintenance of T cell immunity.
Typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Interferon gamma (166 aa, ~19 kDa) is encoded by the human IFNG gene. This protein is involved in antiviral activity, macrophage activation, antiproliferative activity and immunopotentiation.: A position on a scale measuring intensity, quality, or amount.

Concepts.definition: Interferon gamma (166 aa, ~19 kDa) is encoded by the human IFNG gene. This protein is involved in antiviral activity, macrophage activation, antiproliferative activity and immunopotentiation.
A position on a scale measuring intensity, quality, or amount.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of immune cell that has granules (small particles) with enzymes that can kill tumor cells or cells infected with a virus. A natural killer cell is a type of white blood cell.: Any process that takes place on the cellular level, though not necessarily restricted to a single cell.

Concepts.definition: Natural killer cells are cells that resemble large granular lymphocytes.  They do not express markers of either T or B cell lineage. They are positive for CD16, CD56, and CD 94.  These cells do possess Fc receptors for IgG and can kill target cells using antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity. They can also use perforin to kill cells in the absence of antibody and killing may occur without previous sensitization.
Any process that takes place on the cellular level, though not necessarily restricted to a single cell.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A change in the nucleotide sequence of the XIAP gene.: Typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.

Concepts.definition: A change in the nucleotide sequence of the XIAP gene.
Typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Two highly conserved members of the signal transducer and activator of transcription (STAT) protein family, STAT5A and STAT5B. Constitutive phosphorylation of STAT5 proteins, which leads to constitutive activation and aberrant expression of STAT5-dependent genes, has been observed in various neoplastic diseases.: The creation of a phosphate derivative of an organic molecule. This is usually achieved by transferring a phosphate group from ATP via the action of a kinase.

Concepts.definition: Two highly conserved members of the signal transducer and activator of transcription (STAT) protein family, STAT5A and STAT5B. Constitutive phosphorylation of STAT5 proteins, which leads to constitutive activation and aberrant expression of STAT5-dependent genes, has been observed in various neoplastic diseases.
The creation of a phosphate derivative of an organic molecule. This is usually achieved by transferring a phosphate group from ATP via the action of a kinase.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (502 aa, ~53 kDa) is encoded by the human WAS gene. This protein is involved in the regulation of GTPase activity.: Typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.

Concepts.definition: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (502 aa, ~53 kDa) is encoded by the human WAS gene. This protein is involved in the regulation of GTPase activity.
Typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A subset of mature B-lymphocytes that are formed during primary antigen exposure, survive for many years after the infection has resolved and maintain specificity toward the primary antigen. These cells can quickly produce a large amount of antigen-specific antibodies in response to a subsequent exposure.: Determining the number or amount of something.

Concepts.definition: A subset of mature B-lymphocytes that are formed during primary antigen exposure, survive for many years after the infection has resolved and maintain specificity toward the primary antigen. These cells can quickly produce a large amount of antigen-specific antibodies in response to a subsequent exposure.
Determining the number or amount of something.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The determination of the amount of cytokine receptor common subunit gamma present in a sample.

Concepts.longName: Cytokine Receptor Common Subunit Gamma Measurement
Concepts.definition: The determination of the amount of cytokine receptor common subunit gamma present in a sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A change in the nucleotide sequence of the SH2D1A gene.: Typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.

Concepts.definition: A change in the nucleotide sequence of the SH2D1A gene.
Typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: This gene plays a role in the activation of natural killer cells.: Typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.

Concepts.definition: This gene plays a role in the activation of natural killer cells.
Typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The creation of a phosphate derivative of an organic molecule. This is usually achieved by transferring a phosphate group from ATP via the action of a kinase.: Expressed in diverse tissues, Protein Kinase B (AKT/RAC Family) is a group (Alpha, Beta and Gamma) of cytoplasmic serine/threonine enzymes that covalently transfer the terminal, gamma phosphate group from ATP to a variety of substrate proteins and regulate cell signaling responses to insulin, PDGF, and IGF1 (through PI3K) involved in cell survival, cell proliferation, differentiation, apoptosis, glycogen synthesis, and glucose uptake.

Concepts.definition: The creation of a phosphate derivative of an organic molecule. This is usually achieved by transferring a phosphate group from ATP via the action of a kinase.

Expressed in diverse tissues, Protein Kinase B (AKT/RAC Family) is a group (Alpha, Beta and Gamma) of cytoplasmic serine/threonine enzymes that covalently transfer the terminal, gamma phosphate group from ATP to a variety of substrate proteins and regulate cell signaling responses to insulin, PDGF, and IGF1 (through PI3K) involved in cell survival, cell proliferation, differentiation, apoptosis, glycogen synthesis, and glucose uptake.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/03/2015.
ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 2023.3.7 Alt VM added per ticket request CADSR0002119. ak

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A subset of helper T-lymphocytes which synthesize and secrete the interleukins (IL), IL-17A, -21 and -22. These cytokines mediate inflammation by increasing chemokine production, which leads to the recruitment of both monocytes and neutrophils to sites of infection or inflammation. Th17 cells modulate both host immunity against extracellular bacteria and fungi and inflammation. Overexpression of these cells is associated with tissue injury caused by autoimmune diseases.

Concepts.definition: A subset of helper T-lymphocytes which synthesize and secrete the interleukins (IL), IL-17A, -21 and -22. These cytokines mediate inflammation by increasing chemokine production, which leads to the recruitment of both monocytes and neutrophils to sites of infection or inflammation. Th17 cells modulate both host immunity against extracellular bacteria and fungi and inflammation. Overexpression of these cells is associated with tissue injury caused by autoimmune diseases.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: This gene is involved in signal transduction and activation of transcription. It plays a role in regulation of T-helper cell differentiation.: The creation of a phosphate derivative of an organic molecule. This is usually achieved by transferring a phosphate group from ATP via the action of a kinase.

Concepts.definition: This gene is involved in signal transduction and activation of transcription. It plays a role in regulation of T-helper cell differentiation.
The creation of a phosphate derivative of an organic molecule. This is usually achieved by transferring a phosphate group from ATP via the action of a kinase.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: This gene plays a role in signal transduction and activation of transcription. It is involved in regulation of both apoptosis and cell growth.: The creation of a phosphate derivative of an organic molecule. This is usually achieved by transferring a phosphate group from ATP via the action of a kinase.

Concepts.definition: This gene plays a role in signal transduction and activation of transcription. It is involved in regulation of both apoptosis and cell growth.
The creation of a phosphate derivative of an organic molecule. This is usually achieved by transferring a phosphate group from ATP via the action of a kinase.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: This gene plays a role in signal transduction and activation of transcription. It is involved in cell organization/biogenesis.: The creation of a phosphate derivative of an organic molecule. This is usually achieved by transferring a phosphate group from ATP via the action of a kinase.

Concepts.definition: This gene plays a role in signal transduction and activation of transcription. It is involved in cell organization/biogenesis.
The creation of a phosphate derivative of an organic molecule. This is usually achieved by transferring a phosphate group from ATP via the action of a kinase.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Proteins present within the ribosomal subunits. In eukaryotes there are 50 proteins in the large subunit and 33 in the small subunit.: This gene plays a role in the modulation of cell growth and proliferation.

Concepts.definition: Proteins present within the ribosomal subunits. In eukaryotes there are 50 proteins in the large subunit and 33 in the small subunit.
This gene plays a role in the modulation of cell growth and proliferation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: This gene is involved in purine catabolism.: A position on a scale measuring intensity, quality, or amount.

Concepts.definition: This gene is involved in purine catabolism.
A position on a scale measuring intensity, quality, or amount.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A species of Herpetoviridae that is responsible for infectious mononucleosis (glandular fever). Discovered in 1964, this virus has been associated with Burkitt's lymphoma in South African children and with nasopharyngeal carcinoma in Asian populations.: An application of PCR that measures the products generated during each cycle of the polymerase chain reaction process in order to determine the starting amount of template in the reaction.

Concepts.definition: A species of Herpetoviridae that is responsible for infectious mononucleosis (glandular fever). Discovered in 1964, this virus has been associated with Burkitt's lymphoma in South African children and with nasopharyngeal carcinoma in Asian populations.
An application of PCR that measures the products generated during each cycle of the polymerase chain reaction process in order to determine the starting amount of template in the reaction.

PermissibleValues.value: In vitro T cell proliferation to anti-CD3/CD28
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: In vitro T cell proliferation to anti-CD3/CD28

ValueMeaning.preferredName: In vitro T cell proliferation to anti-CD3/CD28
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A relative measurement (ratio or percentage) of T-lymphocyte proliferation due to stimulation by an antigen of interest to a non-stimulated T-lymphocyte proliferation control.

Concepts.definition: A relative measurement (ratio or percentage) of T-lymphocyte proliferation due to stimulation by an antigen of interest to a non-stimulated T-lymphocyte proliferation control.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A heterotetrameric complex comprised of two molecules of interleukin-10 receptor subunit alpha and two molecules interleukin-10 receptor subunit beta. This receptor complex has high affinity for interleukin-10 and modulates interleukin signaling.: Typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.

Concepts.definition: A heterotetrameric complex comprised of two molecules of interleukin-10 receptor subunit alpha and two molecules interleukin-10 receptor subunit beta. This receptor complex has high affinity for interleukin-10 and modulates interleukin signaling.
Typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: HLA-DR expression on monocytes and B cells

ValueMeaning.preferredName: HLA-DR expression on monocytes and B cells
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The determination of the amount of HLA-DR protein present in a sample.

Concepts.definition: The determination of the amount of HLA-DR protein present in a sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A measurement of the total tumor necrosis factor (cachexin) cytokine in a biological specimen.

Concepts.definition: The determination of the amount of tumor necrosis factor present in a sample.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: CD4+ CD25++ FOXP3+ Treg cell count

ValueMeaning.preferredName: CD4+ CD25++ FOXP3+ Treg cell count
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The determination of the number of regulatory T-lymphocytes expressing CD4, CD25 and FOXP3 present in a sample.

Concepts.longName: CD4, CD25, FOXP3 Expressing Regulatory T-Lymphocyte Count
Concepts.definition: The determination of the number of regulatory T-lymphocytes expressing CD4, CD25 and FOXP3 present in a sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: This gene is involved in the regulation of lymphopoiesis.: Typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.

Concepts.definition: This gene is involved in the regulation of lymphopoiesis.
Typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A purine nucleoside component of DNA comprised of adenosine linked by its N9 nitrogen to the C1 carbon of deoxyribose.: The monomeric units from which DNA or RNA polymers are constructed. They consist of a purine or pyrimidine base, a pentose sugar, and a phosphate group. (From King & Stansfield, A Dictionary of Genetics, 4th ed): A position on a scale measuring intensity, quality, or amount.

Concepts.definition: A purine nucleoside component of DNA comprised of adenosine linked by its N9 nitrogen to the C1 carbon of deoxyribose.

A subunit of DNA or RNA consisting of a nitrogenous base (adenine, guanine, thymine, or cytosine in DNA; adenine, guanine, uracil, or cytosine in RNA), a phosphate molecule, and a sugar molecule (deoxyribose in DNA and ribose in RNA).
A position on a scale measuring intensity, quality, or amount.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: This gene plays a role in hydrolysis of adenosine.: A position on a scale measuring intensity, quality, or amount.

Concepts.definition: This gene plays a role in hydrolysis of adenosine.
A position on a scale measuring intensity, quality, or amount.
